TopicTitle: Apollo Mission Recreation (And More!) [Requesting Ground Crew Aid!]

Articles.Content:
1. If that's what the probes made for, then ofc. Your payload engineer, I'll put it where you tell me.

2. It is a major maneuver.

3. Again yes.

You tell me, can the booster/payload make it to the planned destination? We'll follow whatever plan you have for us.

The transfer stage (which I'm calling the D-979) can make it to a geostationary, 0o inclination orbit with >500 m/s Ã¢Ë†â€ V to spare, but that's a really long travel time- 10 hours from GTO burn to circularization burn, plus up to 24 hours of tiny orbital adjustments.

So, here's what I suggest: burn to orbit with the first and second stages of the S-IB. Decouple the S-IVB200. While you guys run systems checks on the payload, I'll deorbit the S-IVB200. After about a half orbit of the payload, we burn at the ascending node to put our apogee at the descending node, with an altitude of 35,786 kilometers. Then we recheck the payload and transfer stage, plot a burn to circularize, and end the simulation, assuming that the company we put the satellite up for will circularize, and decouple the payload, and conduct station-keeping on the orbit.

The steps, in general order, are:

Disable RCS on the payload and D-979

Burn S-IB stage

Decouple S-IB stage, fire retro and ullage motors

Engage RCS

Ignite S-IVB200 stage

Release payload fairings

Burn to an optimal 200 km orbit

Cut J-2 engine

Separate payload and D-979 from S-IVB200

Enable RCS on the D-979

Run systems checks on the payload and D-979

Plot deorbit burn for S-IVB200

Plot GTO burn for D-979

Deorbit S-IVB200 and burn D-979 for GTO

Run systems checks on the D-979 and payload

Plot circularization and inclination change burn

end sim

The transfer stage (which I'm calling the D-979) can make it to a geostationary, 0o inclination orbit with >500 m/s Ã¢Ë†â€ V to spare, but that's a really long travel time- 10 hours from GTO burn to circularization burn, plus up to 24 hours of tiny orbital adjustments.

So, here's what I suggest: burn to orbit with the first and second stages of the S-IB. Decouple the S-IVB200. While you guys run systems checks on the payload, I'll deorbit the S-IVB200. After about a half orbit of the payload, we burn at the ascending node to put our apogee at the descending node, with an altitude of 35,786 kilometers. Then we recheck the payload and transfer stage, plot a burn to circularize, and end the simulation, assuming that the company we put the satellite up for will circularize, and decouple the payload, and conduct station-keeping on the orbit.

The steps, in general order, are:

Disable RCS on the payload and D-979

Burn S-IB stage

Decouple S-IB stage, fire retro and ullage motors

Engage RCS

Ignite S-IVB200 stage

Release payload fairings

Burn to an optimal 200 km orbit

Cut J-2 engine

Separate payload and D-979 from S-IVB200

Enable RCS on the D-979

Run systems checks on the payload and D-979

Plot deorbit burn for S-IVB200

Plot GTO burn for D-979

Deorbit S-IVB200 and burn D-979 for GTO

Run systems checks on the D-979 and payload

Plot circularization and inclination change burn

end sim
